data: The Open Pharmacological Concepts Triple Store

Drug discovery is data-hungry and all major pharmaceutical companies maintain extensive in-house instances of public data alongside internal. Analysis and hypothesis generation for drug-discovery projects requires assembly, overlay and comparison of data from many sources, requiring shared identifiers and common semantics. Expression profiles need to be overlaid with gene or pathway identifiers and reports on compound pharmacology. Alignment and integration of internal and public data and information sources is a significant effort and the process is repeated across companies, institutes and academic laboratories. This represents a significant waste and an opportunity cost.
 
To address these challenges, the Open PHACTS project will develop an open access innovation platform, Open Pharmacological Space (OPS), via a semantic web approach. OPS will comprise data, vocabularies and infrastructure needed to accelerate drug-oriented research. This semantic integration hub will remove key bottlenecks in small molecule drug discovery: disparate information sources, lack of standards and common identifiers, guided by well defined research questions from drug discovery. 

Workflows for data capture, processing, interoperability, visualization, and chemogenomics will be developed creating a comprehensive Systems Chemical Biology Analysis Network. Security issues around proprietary data, shared via the Open PHACTS Discovery Platform and accessible for safe querying and reasoning will be properly addressed with expert trusted parties.

The Open PHACTS consortium comprises 20 European academic and SME partners, with leading experts in the fields of data mining, annotation, small molecule data storage and manipulation, target bioinformatics, RDF information handling, massive in silico reasoning and chemical biology. The 10 EFPIA members of Open PHACTS will contribute drug discovery expertise, data sets, software engineering and programming capacity to the project.
OntoWiki – Semantic Collaboration for Enterprise Knowledge Management, E-Learning and E-Tourism

The aim of this project is to prepare and start-up the commercial exploitation of the semantic collaboration software OntoWiki in the three different target markets, namely Enterprise Knowledge Management, semantically enhanced content management for E-Learning and E-Tourism. OntoWiki is a comprehensive open-source platform for social semantic collaboration. It is developed at Universität Leipzig and has a large and active user base. Within the course of the project OntoWiki will be further developed and adopted to the needs of the SME for exploitation of OntoWiki in the prospective target markets.
Making the Web an Exploratory for Geospatial Knowledge

The advent of the Data Web demonstrates how Web technologies can be employed to integrate dispersed, heterogeneous information. Most information – be it the product logistics status within supply chains, data warehouses of E-Commerce systems or offerings of the bakery shop next door – has a directly or indirectly associated spatial dimension. Integrating and efficiently using information with such a spatial dimension on the Web poses very particular challenges. First, we have to combine and reason about spatial and semantic features that use different vocabularies and representation techniques. Second, the wealth of pre-existing overlapping and complementary information sources in the spatial domain demands information management able to deal with billions of facts in a scalable manner. Third, only by dramatically lowering the entrance barriers extra value can be generated through the involvement of thousands of non-expert end users in authoring, curation and assessment. GeoKnow tackles these challenges and facilitates the transition from islands of isolated Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to a Web of interlinked Geographic Knowledge Systems (GKS). GeoKnow focuses on two complementary application scenarios: (1) spatial-semantic collaboration and data integration along value-chains in supplier and customers networks; and (2) spatial-semantic travel E-Commerce data management. GeoKnow will contribute to the evolution of the Web from a medium for information exchange to a medium for (spatial) knowledge integration. GeoKnow aims to help realizing network effects by increasing quality and coherence of the Spatial Data Web. For enterprises, the GeoKnow Generator will provide a cost-efficient way to integrate a variety of heterogeneous information sources within an Enterprise Data Intranet.

Non-relational data management is emerging as a critical need for the new data economy based on large, distributed, heterogeneous, and complexly structured data sets. This new data management paradigm also provides an opportunity for research results to impact young innovative companies working on new RDF and graph data management technologies to start playing a significant role in this new data economy.Standards and benchmarking are two of the most important factors for the development of new information technology, yet there is still no comprehensive suite of benchmarks and benchmarking practices for RDF and graph databases, nor is there an authority for setting benchmark definitions and auditing official results. Without them, the future development and uptake of these technologies is at risk by not providing industry with clear, user-driven targets for performance and functionality.The goal of the Linked Data Benchmark Council (LDBC) project is to create the first comprehensive suite of open, fair and vendor-neutral benchmarks for RDF/graph databases together with the LDBC foundation which will define processes for obtaining, auditing and publishing results. The core scientific innovation of LDBC is therefore to define meaningful benchmarks derived from a combination of actual usage scenarios combined with the technical insight of top database systems researchers and architects in the choke points of current technology. LDBC will bring together a broad community of researchers and RDF and graph database vendors to establish an independent authority, the LDBC foundation, responsible for specifying benchmarks, benchmarking procedures and verifying/publishing results. The forum created will become a long-surviving, industry supported association similar to the TPC. Vendors and user organisations will participate in order to influence benchmark design and to make use of the obvious marketing opportunities.
Fusepool Publish-Process-Perform Platform for Linked Data

To make publishing and processing of linked data easy, the proposed project develops a set of integrated software components based on open-source Linked Data Platform best practices.  The tightly integrated components support the multilingual data value chain from data exploration (e.g. identifying structured and unstructured data sources), extraction (e.g. using named entity recognition, RDF conversion), enrichment (e.g. interlinking, crowdsourcing), and delivery (e.g. analytics, apps for desktop and mobile devices). These components run on an open-source data platform with various enterprise-grade storage solutions.The vision is to make publishing and reuse of linked data as easy as possible for the end user thanks to a thriving market economy with data publishers, developers, and consumers along the value chain. Making data reusable and interoperable within and outside the organization requires a fundamentally different ap-proach to 'storing' knowledge. 'The best name is probably a Logical Data Warehouse...because it focuses on the logic of information ...[for] giving integrated access to all forms of information assets.'  Only with integrated access to the data is it possible to have apps on top of that data that scale across single use cases and provide real added value.Fusepool LDAP (Linked Data Analytics Processing) derives its name from the idea of fusing and pooling linked data with analytical processing on top of it. Because linked data is multidimensional data, it lends itself to analytical processing such as consolidation (e.g. aggregation within a dimension), drill-down (e.g. navigating through the details), and slicing and dicing (e.g. viewing an aspect from different dimensions). However, an integrated publishing and processing workflow with integrated user interfaces is still missing. The lack of an integrated publishing and processing environment makes it difficult and time-consuming for data publishers and consumers to engage with linked data.
LOD2 - Creating Knowledge out of Interlinked Data

Over the last 3 years, the semantic web activity has gained momentum with the widespread publishing of structured data as RDF. The Linked Data paradigm has therefore evolved from a practical research idea into a very promising candidate for addressing one of the biggest challenges in the area of intelligent information management: the exploitation of the Web as a platform for data and information integration in addition to document search. To translate this initial success into a world-scale disruptive reality, encompassing the Web 2.0 world and enterprise data alike, the following research challenges need to be addressed: improve coherence and quality of data published on the Web, close the performance gap between relational and RDF data management, establish trust on the Linked Data Web and generally lower the entrance barrier for data publishers and users. With partners among those who initiated and strongly supported the Linked Open Data initiative, the LOD2 project aims at tackling these challenges by developing:1. enterprise-ready tools and methodologies for exposing and managing very large amounts of structured information on the Data Web,2. a testbed and bootstrap network of high-quality multi-domain, multi-lingual ontologies from sources such as Wikipedia and OpenStreetMap.3. machine learning algorithms for automatically enriching, repairing, interlinking and fusing data from the Web.4. standards and methods for reliably tracking provenance, ensuring privacy and data security as well as for assessing the quality of information.5. adaptive tools for searching, browsing, and authoring of Linked Data.We will integrate and syndicate linked data with large-scale, existing applications and showcase the benefits in the three application scenarios media & publishing, corporate data intranets and e-government.
Holistic Benchmarking of Big Linked Data

Linked Data has gained significant momentum over the last years. It is now used at industrial scale in many sectors in which an increasingly large amount of rapidly changing data needs to be processed. HOBBIT is an ambitious project that aims to push the development of Big Linked Data (BLD) processing solutions by providing a family of industry-relevant benchmarks for the BLD value chain through a generic evaluation platform. 
We aim to make open deterministic benchmarks available to test the performance of existing systems and push the development of innovative industry-relevant solutions. The underlying data will mimic real industrial data assembled during the course of the project. At the beginning of the project, HOBBIT will work on roughly 1PB of real industry-relevant data from 4 different domains. The data will be extended through collaborations during the project. 
To push the use of the benchmarks, we will organize or join challenges that aim to measure the performance of technologies for the different steps of the BLD lifecycle. In contrast to existing benchmarks, we will provide modular and easily extensible benchmarks for all industry-relevant BLD processing steps that allow to assess whole suites of software that cover more than one step.
The infrastructure necessary to run the evaluation campaigns will be made available. Our architecture will rely on web interfaces and cloud infrastructures to ensure scalability. The open HOBBIT platform will make human- and machine-readable, public periodic reports available. As exit strategy, the project will create an association after the second project year that will be sustained by the means of subscriptions from industry and academia and associated with existing benchmarking associations. The clear portfolio of added value for the members will be defined in the early project stages and disseminated throughout the evaluation campaigns.
KGYAT have developed the RVCR, the world’s first commercially viable Rotary Variable Compression Ratio (VCR) engine.

'KGYAT have developed RVCR, the world’s first commercially viable Variable Compression Ratio (VCR) engine. KGYAT’s proprietary RVCR (Rotary Variable Compression Ratio) engine technology combines into one high-tech powertrain the specific output and performance advantages of rotary motors and the thermal efficiency gains from VCRs. This enables the RVCR engine to eliminate the complexities in conventional crank mechanism-based VCRs and offer the advantages of; multiple fuel flexibility, efficiency gains by 30%, lower emissions, and reduced cost, making it the world’s first commercially viable VCR engine. This disruptive, highly efficient fuel-flexible RVCR engine will enable a smooth transition from 20th century fossil fuel dependency to 21st century green fuels without disrupting the existing fossil-fuel based economic structures.
RVCR has been prototyped within a laboratory environment, however KGYAT is now looking to gain funding to: demonstrate and validate the performance of a 75kW RVCR engine on a test bed for product qualification; and industrialisation of the RVCR engine with an engine manufacturer, including a design for manufacturing and assembly and the optimisation of costs, demonstrating viability of high volume production. 
Due to RVCR’s robustness and efficiency it is a perfect solution to reduce emissions and fuel consumption of passenger cars.'

This Project focuses on raising quality of educational system as well as development of teacher training.

The main aim of the project is to raise the quality of school functioning through raising teachers’ professional competences who work in The Maria Grzegorzewska Schools of Special Educational Needs  in Zdunska Wola  with other educational and management  institutions  cooperating with our school through financial support of participation in foreign trainings.

Realization of the project enables participants to raise professional qualifications in the range of Montessori Pedagogy when training, visiting institutions that use Montessori Method in everyday work as well as during international Congress of Montessori-Europe. It will make  possible for these institutions to work out a model of raising professional and language competence of teachers with usage of foreign mobility.

Another  purpose of this project is systematic raising of educational quality and in-service training for teachers. Our participation in foreign mobility will help us in meeting new people and establishing international contacts as a result of this action. Staying abroad will raise our intercultural competence and will result in dissemination the attitude of tolerance and respect towards other cultures. The project will be beneficial not only for participant but also for institutions. The main aim of the project is to support institutions working in the fields of education and teacher training, creating professional structure of foreign mobility for students, teachers and all school staff. Actions presented in this project are not focused only on  in – service training but also on foreign mobility that will establish international cooperation in the long run. This strategy will help to collaborate within European network of educational institutions. All the actions provided will contribute to improvement of  educational offer as well as gaining modern and dynamic institution that will benefit in raising interest in our school.  All participants will take advantage of this international experience by raising their professional competence, and learning more about psychology, pedagogy and Montessori Method. Thanks to participation in the project, our teachers will contribute to development of educational quality and high standards of teaching. At the same time it will give an opportunity to disseminate achievements, better results, practice in Montessori pedagogy and European educational system. The assumption of the projects is solidifying  the main idea of Montessori pedagogy and indicating values that influence social uniformity, active citizenship, intercultural dialogue, gender equality, and self-fulfillment.

The project encourages to better usage of  results, innovative products and processes,  and to exchange experience in the field of Montessori Methodology in order to improve educational quality.

Astangu Vocational Rehabilitation Centre is an organization providing educational and  rehabilitation courses to people with disabilities. To be able to offer flexible and needs based educational options to our trainees and to support them on the way to labour market, we need to  continuously  improve the competences of staff and our way of working. 

Our trainees are people with disabilities who are often marginalized due to their disability, and/or economical, social or health problems and are often neglected from the society. 

Feedback from companies where our trainees pass their internship confirms that the level of professional competences of our trainees are satisfactory but they lack of social skills. By analysing the content of vocational training curricula and supportive services we have decided to put more attention to supporting trainees’ self-awareness, motivation, communication skills and personal goals. At the same time we need to continue with high level professional education where diverse practice in companies plays an important role. 

The project „Employment and Empowerment“  for mobility of trainees and staff members has to main aims: 

First  aim is to offer a professional European mobility for Software and Database Management trainees to support their competitiveness through growth of their professional and social skills. The aim is fulfilled by working and living in foreign environment. 

Second aim is to develop competences of staff through exploring new methods and approaches in supporting trainees’ self-awareness, motivation, communication skills  and setting personal goals. These skills are important for trainees to be able to conciously participate in a learning process and in moving towerd labour market.   

8 trainees from Software and database management course will get an opportunity to participate in a 2-weeks internship in German vocational education centre for people with disabilities, 4 trainees from the same speciality will spend 2 weeks in workpractice in a company in Finland. 4 saff members will get to know the learning and employment support methods in England during 1 week’s mobility. 

Project manager will be contracted to be responsible for implementing the project according to the project contract and timetable. Implementing this mobility project is part of Astangu’s work plan and monitoring will be organised within a regular work process in weekly management information meetings and review of the work plan. 

New professional skills, knowledge, improved social and everyday coping skills, raised self-awareness, self-esteem and motivation, progressed foreign language skills and cultural consciousness  will be the results of trainees participating in European mobility project.  Staff members are expected to gain new professional  skills to support our trainees in self-awareness, in raising their motivation, communication skills and abilities to set their personal goals. Work motivation and willingness to improve the work processes in Astangu, cultural horizon and foreign language skills will be improved during the visit to English organisation that supports disadvantaged people in moving towards labour market. 



Cooperation between ptoject partners will strenghten on organisational as well as personal level. Long term impact of the project will be seen in further development of our courses and services (including starting to use new approaches, methods in work) and in employment placements due to the good experiences from the mobilities.  By fulfilling the aims of the project we also support the impelemntation of Astangu’s, Estonia’s and Europe’s  important long term strategies, including increasing employemnt options, social inclusion and innovation.

Youth participation in Europe is generally low, based on the findings of the Flash Barometer Report of 2013. Young people tend tobe inactive when it comes to participation in the civic society, with only a 23% percent of young people being involved as avolunteer, according to statistics on the European Union. It would be of high importance for young people to understand the valueand importance of volunteering, mostly because through being a volunteer, they would develop a sense of active citizenship andinterest in their local communities.Additionally, there is a lack of sense of European identity among citizens of the European Union. According to the findings of theStandard Eurobarometer 77, the majority of European citizens feel strongly attached to their own countries or their localcommunities, while only 8% of them feel a strong attachment to the European Union.Through the Erasmus+ program and its opportunities, these numbers could be improved, however, in some parts of the EuropeanUnion, especially the Nordic countries and the United Kingdom, there is a lack of interest in the mobilities offered by the program. Itis the experience of the team of InterCollege that even though young people living in Aalborg are generally active in thecommunity, they have a lack of interest when it comes to mobility opportunities and have difficulties to relate to issues of theEuropean Union. Many young people the team members has interacted with have a lack of European identity.It has been proven that taking part in a mobility changes the attitude of the individual towards European issues, as well as motivatesthem to be an active citizen in their local community. Through the mobilities, young people develop a healthy awareness of theirown potential and realize the importance of the action of every individual. Young people returning from mobilities have been moreactive in their communities, and were much likely to volunteer. Statistics show that young people have showed more initiative andself-awareness, and have develop a sense of connection to Europe and European Identity after having started volunteering.By interacting with the volunteers of InterCollege, who will be encouraged to meet with the local community in their free time, aswell as be expected to organize local activities aimed at young people, young people will become naturally more interested inmobility possibilities and are expected to be motivated in applying themselves. As the local activities organized by the volunteerswill be within the theme of active citizenship, entrepreneurship and European identity, they will act the main tools for theirpromotion.The aim of this project is to promote mobility and to foster volunteerism in Europe through active participation.The aim will be reached through the following objectives:1. Promoting mobility opportunities for young people.2. Promoting positive awareness of the European Union among young people.3. Promoting European identity among young people, both in program and partner countries.4. Promoting active citizenship and volunteerism among young people.The selected volunteers all have experiences with youth work to some extent, either as a participant of youth mobility or as anorganizer of a project activity. They all expressed their interest in gaining experience with project management and interculturalprojects. They would also like to engage themselves in the local community, and learn as much about Denmark and Aalborg aspossible. All of the volunteers would like to engage themselves within the youth sector after their EVS and applied toInterCollege in the hopes that they will acquire the necessary skills and competences.All the participants have been working as volunteers before in their free time, therefore, they have experienced the positiveoutcomes of it, however, they feel that they need to demonstrate their dedication even further. Participating in EVS will give themthis opportunity, as they will be involved in full-time volunteerism.It is expected that through interaction with the volunteers and as a result of their dissemination, the numbers of mobilitiesacross Europe will be higher. As a consequence to that, young people over Europe will become more aware of the importance ofbeing an active citizen, the positive effects of volunteering and develop an enhanced level of European identity.
Young proffesionals!  Say no to bullies!!!

The "Young professionals! Say no to bullies !!! "is a multi-purpose project addressed to youth workers, young people joining the labor market, people associated with organizations that support victims of bullying, discrimination, sexual harassment.The idea of ​​the project stems from the needs of young people who enter the labor market and faced with difficult situations at work, they do not have full knowledge of the realities of life, as well as the needs of organizations that seek knowledge and tools to counteract these phenomena. In regions particularly affected by unemployment problem of bullying, sexual harassment, discrimination is disturbing and affects mostly young people who start their professional lives.The project involves two main activities: Seminar, which will take place in Lublin, 10-17 November 2016. And aims to exchange experiences, information on. The problem of bullying, discrimination, sexual harassment, and a meeting of experts to compare the situation in the countries of the partner organizations . Seminar to draw attention to the essence of the problem and its knowledge, identify the needs of young people understand the consequences of the pathology of the labor market, as well as the possibility of countermeasures. The seminar will be used for research reports on social. Situation of young people on the labor market - job satisfaction, working conditions, so you will need to meet the needs of young people. During the seminar, participants will meet with representatives of the State Labour Inspectorate and the National Association of Antymobbingowego OSA, to get to know two Polish key organizations granting support to people in difficulty in the work environment.The seminar will end directed to the concerned Open Day Seminar with open workshops and open debate.Training will be preceded by a competition for the password anti-bullying and anti-discrimination directed to the local community and a mini social campaign in the local community and on the Internet and will be held in Kościelisko 16-22 February 2017 and is open to participants of the seminar working with young people, the future multipliers, who together will work out with the trainers script program antymobbingowego of an information workshop, which will be able to implement in their local communities.The project will help to draw attention to the w / the problems, to the discussion, to develop tools to counter the phenomenon. In the long term, undertaken discussions may be the beginning of social change, develop new attitudes, social standards.The project will be attended by representatives of the countries, i.e. Poland, Great Britain, Greece, Ukraine, Latvia, Egypt, FYROM, Serbia, Armenia, Italy, Romania, Hungary, Belarus, the Russian Federation, Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Creativity in Early Years and Pre-school Education

Croydon is undergoing an exciting transformation, and is well on its way to becoming a modern European city where education aims to provide a place that unleashes and nurtures local talent and is recognised for its support and opportunity for lifelong learning and ambitions for children and young people
Croydon education aims to provide a place that unleashes and nurtures local talent and is recognised  for its support and opportunity for lifelong learning and ambitions for children and young people. 
The consortium is led by Croydon LA and includes 17 schools (primary and pre-primary stage).
Our application aims to support the  Community Strategy by providing its partners with the opportunity to come together and work on enhancing practice across all schools by working on addressing shared objectives across 2 main strategic areas:

Area 1
Pedagogy and Creativity: Develop creativity across the curriculum through training and experience of creative approaches in Europe and develop teaching and learning of educators through experiencing education in other countries
Area 2
Pedagogy and Internationalisation :  Developing teaching and learning of educators through experiencing education in other countries

These 2 main strategic areas are at the basis of our European development plan which has the following objectives proposed: 
* Enhance teaching and learning by raising staff expertise and competences within a European context
* Enhance and develop creativity in Early Years
* Enhance and develop a multicultural approach to learning
* Develop further child initiated learning and implement and enhance the creativity in schools
* Develop innovative approaches to teaching and learning
* Develop inter-cultural understanding in view of breaking down barriers through social changes 
* Internationalisation of the curriculum through observation and evaluation of  curriculum models in other countries 
* Develop links with schools in Europe,  to broaden cultural understanding of both children and staff

In order to meet our objectives, we have devised a mobility plan which will see 34 staff from the 17 partner schools attend a structured training course in Italy (in November 2018 and in March 2019): Creative approaches in early years and pre-school education, Bologna Italy. The course is provided by  an experienced training provider: http://www.schooleducationgateway.eu/en/pub/profile.cfm?do=organisation&id=542)
This course is designed for early years, pre-school and primary staff, and aims to improve knowledge and understanding of creative approaches in early years education. The course is delivered in a region renowned for excellence in early years provision. It includes visits to schools in Modena to observe and evaluate teaching practice in ‘another and a visit to the Reggio Children Centre to provide teachers and educators with the opportunity to learn about the approaches used by experts form the centre. 

Staff attending will be selected based on a selection plan and will include staff ranging from head teachers, teaching and non-teaching staff, stage and curriculum leaders selected on the basis of their role, motivation, development needs, ability to lead change in school and across the authority.

Specific teams of staff will be attending mobilities and will form a CPD training team that will be able to cascade learning upon their return into school and across the schools in the networks.
 
Specific dissemination activities will include staff training, presentation, conferences , development of a visual record, teaching and learning booklet, in school activities which will reach in the first instance 6346 children and 978 staff.

Through our structured approach to staff mobilities, we foresee the project to generate a number of outcomes and impacts:
* Enhanced Early Years and Pre-school provision
* Enhanced teaching and learning by raising staff expertise and competences within a European context
* Enhanced and developed creativity in Early Years
* Developed further child-initiated learning and implement and enhance the creativity in schools
* Enhanced and developed a multicultural approach to learning
* Developed innovative approaches to teaching and learning
* Developed inter-cultural understanding in view of breaking down barriers through social changes 
* Internationalisation of the curriculum through observation and evaluation of  curriculum models in other countries 
* Developed links with schools in Europe,  to broaden cultural understanding of both children and staff

We would expect that staff will come back from activities having developed teaching and learning techniques, knowledge,  competences, a better understanding of European systems, cultural understanding, increased language skills , enthusiasm which in turn will be passed on to other staff in school, to pupils and staff also in schools within the authority, therefore supporting the development of Croydon education as a whole.
Enhancing teaching and learning through a European CPD strategy

There has been an increased focus on improving education at European level and  moving towards a curriculum that believes that all children and young people have the right to have their individual needs met.  A well performing education system supports change through evaluation and reflection on methodologies that allows educators to break down barriers to learning and provide pupils with an innovative and creative learning journey.

Improving the quality of teaching and learning through an active research and internationalisation plan that supports the development the skills of those involved in providing such education, is paramount in achieving excellence in education and increasing the participation rates and fulfillment into society. The teaching standards for example 'encourage educators to develop the knowledge, skills, practices, and dispositions they need to help learners perform at higher levels.'

Croydon is undergoing an exciting transformation, and is well on its way to becoming a modern European city where education plays a key role in making it a place that unleashes and nurtures local talent and is recognised  for its support and opportunity for lifelong learning and ambitions for children and young people.

This project aims brings together 16 schools who will work together to enhance practice across all schools in the consortium and the wider community by addressing shared objectives across 4 main strategic areas:
1. Pedagogy  & didactics: Developing teaching and learning of teaching and non-teaching staff through the experience and observation of practice and training in other countries with a clear focus of visual literacy and ICT)
2. Innovation and Creativity:  Develop creativity across the curriculum through training and experience of creative approaches in Europe with a focus of child-initiated learning and outdoor provision
3. Special Education Needs and Disabilities: Develop understanding of special education and disabilities in order to develop appropriate strategies to make learning more effective
4. European Dimension: Developing a curriculum that allows for collaboration, exchange and sharing of practice with peers in Europe
Our European Development Plan aims to provide and  an opportunity to develop practice through experiencing training and learning in Europe. Therefore, our key objectives are:
• Raise achievement and attainment
• Promote and embed critical and reasoning skills
• To enhance pupils' life skills 
• Enhance staff expertise in the areas of early years, outdoor learning and ICT
• Develop innovative and creative approaches to teaching and learning in Early Years and whole school use of information technology 
• Work with staff within the local  and European community to enhance all aspects of teaching and learning thus enabling all children, no matter what their starting point or background, to achieve to the highest standard. 
• Developing the provision and practice within the Early Years through being immersed in a truly child-centred learning environment.
• Developing teachers’ understanding of the opportunities for rich learning in an outdoor environment and how they can facilitate this and ensure it is embedded in all aspects of the curriculum. 
• Developing teachers’ understanding of the value and uses of Visual literacy and ICT to enhance and enrich all learning.
• Developing a deeper understanding of the approaches to the range of SEND needs children present.
• Enhance teaching and learning by raising staff expertise and competences within a European context
• Enhance the teaching and learning through the use of outdoors and forest learning
• Enhance and develop the provision for SEND
• Develop a European Dimension through observation and evaluation of  curriculum models in other countries 
• Develop links with schools in Europe  to broaden cultural understanding and plan for future partnership projects
• Develop innovative approaches to teaching and learning
• Develop leadership skills

Methodology:
Attendance at 4 structured training courses in Italy, Spain, Iceland and Sweden over a period of 12 months where 96 staff from a range of roles and selected through a fair and open process will experience learning in other countries leading to a more enthusiastic, committed and motivate workforce. 
They will work collaboratively to develop new teaching and learning across their schools as well as across the authority as a whole.  
The project will benefit in the wider sense approx 904 staff and 6016 pupils across all of the members through the participation of 96 direct staff form the 16 schools. A number of impacts are envisaged and we are confident that this project will project will support all schools in developing a more exciting curriculum for the children and inspire them to become lifelong learners. This is a goal that will ensure Croydon has learning at the heart of it's long term strategy.

YMSN is a registered social enterprise which offers support to single and young mothers all aged under 30 years.
YMSN was set up by Fiona Small, in 2011. It provides support, training and development to young mothers in deprived areas. It aims to empower young women to make informed decisions about their lifestyle and relationships.
Our social objective is to empower, coach and help young mothers access exciting opportunities to reach their personal goals.

By supporting and developing these young mums we transform young lives with confidence, jobs and enterprise, increasing wealth, wellbeing and social interaction. We ensure that these same young mums become a sustained beacon of onward support and encouragement for others. YMSN aims to be the go to organisation that influences decision makers in creating solutions and strategies for young mums.

The Association for Social-Economic Development and Promotion CATALACTICA was established in January 2001 and was officially recognized under provisions of Ordinance 26/2000 on 8 February 2001. 
The mission of Association CATALACTICA is to support and promote, from a socio-economical perspective, all categories of persons, regardless of their age, gender, nationality or other discriminatory criteria. Catalactica Association has developed over 50 projects aimed at employment and community development with funding from the European Union, Soros Foundation, UNICEF, UNDP, World Bank, ILO, Civil Society Foundation.

Our projects' objectives are:

1. to develop YMSN's  youth workers' skills for supporting our clients to move into employment, by shadowing Catalactica's youth workers and learning from their experience 

2.  to develop YMSN's youth workers' skills for intercultural communication & team work

3. to develop YMSN's knowledge about Erasmus+ and opportunities that can be offered to our young mothers.

Following this project, we hope YMSN will be able to offer new services such as international EVS volunteering, as well as cross-sectorial partnerships with primary schools, for organising international mobilities for children. 

Our project is linked to the objectives of Erasmus+ programmes, as it will support fighting rising levels of unemployment among young mothers, as many of them are leaving school early, with low skills, and became unemployed and socially excluded. The project will enable us to reaching out to marginalised young mothers, promoting diversity and intercultural dialogue.

The Europe 2020 strategy has a clear ambition Europe will succeed if it acts together. Unpinned by key priorities this project aims to contribute to those priorities. Specifically to foster highemployment economy to deliver social and territorial cohesion. The use of creative arts is a proven way to promote wellbeing and fundamentally employability skills. "Off the Wall" will give participants space to not only develop their artistic value but also create positive thinking and boosting self-esteem, all will improve emotional wellbeing. "Off The Wall" will create accessibility and inclusion through art, leading to good mental health and wellbeing. 

All to bring about behaviour change to the participants. This project has a core focus to engage young people in positive activity, through the youth exchange. These young people will be marginalised and often feel dis-enfranchised within their community. There has been an increasing amount of academic and policy literature devoted to the importance of the arts and culture to the well-being, personal growth and social development of the individual within civil society. There has also been an ever-growing body of academic literature attesting to the blurring of boundaries between audience and spectator, professional and amateur arts and continuing debates as to the role of the artist and authorship and to the nature and future of what is termed ‘art’ today. However, very little has been explored concerning the effect of grassroots arts activities, and by this, we mean here amateur arts activities, on the individual and on the communities within which the activities take place. 

Problems to address: Marginalised young people with limited opportunities to understand the digital world in which they live in Poor use of resources and digital media Not feeling motivated or aspiration Low self-awareness and self-knowledge Loss of value, identity and self-esteem Low confidence in potential and social abilities Low employability perspectives and no sense of moral obligation 

Aim - To stimulate the creative mindset of all young people so they can feel confident in communicating and socialising with others in their community. Objective Increased ability to address the needs of marginalised youth who have low self-esteem and self-confidence Improved competencies, linked to youth professionals profiles by exploration, building imagination and creativeness. Understand how to enhance health and wellbeing and improved communication and social skills. Youth workers to Improve International discussion
and networking. To contribute to a sense of pride for young people a Greater understanding of interconnections between formal and non-formal education, Develop new methods about non-formal education through visual arts such as video, photography and graphic design to enhance creativity, critical mind, social cohesion, communication and Fashion. To gather experience of youth workers in the art to exchange best practices To create a space for the exchange of experiences and best practices through workshops. 

Planned activity: Grassroots “Art” in motion, Introduction to different art techniques.  Enhanced inter-cultural awareness and Social development; Improved career prospects; sense of initiative and entrepreneurship; Improved foreign language competences; Use of transversal skills to improving their personal development and employability; Support the professional development in youth to innovating and improving the quality of youth work across Europe; Promote cooperation in the youth fields to open international dimension of organisations active in training and youth fields so that they can offer activities that better respond to the needs of individuals, within and outside Europe; Improve the level of their digital literacy while exchanging experience and good practices.
